author: Julie Gerstein
title: So Apparently People Used To Be Sent To The Mental Hospital For Masturbating
text:
View this image ›
Snopes.com / Via snopes.com ID: 10757340 2. Uh, and this is the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum. View this image ›
Getty Images Haunting you in your nightmares, for sure.
ID: 10757566 3. The asylum was supposed to hold around 250 patients, but at times held as many as 2,400. It officially closed in 1994. View this image ›
Eva Hambach / AFP / Getty Images Its 666 acres contained a working farm, dairy, and cemetery.
ID: 10757569 4. According to the roster, people could be admitted for such delightful things as “female disease,” “laziness,” “menstrual derangement” or, you know, just being “bad company.” View this image ›
Getty Images ID: 10757567 5. To be clear, these weren’t “official diagnoses” of mental illness, just a list of some of the underlying symptoms that asylum officials believed “exacerbated such an illness.” View this image ›
Snopes.com / Via snopes.com Yes, the list included “READING NOVELS.”
ID: 10757657 6. According to author Maureen Dabbagh, who wrote Parental Kidnapping in America: An Historical and Cultural Analysis, which examined the patterns and reasoning behind people being committed in the 1800s, the majority of patients were treated for “acute mania,” “chronic dementia,” or “melancholia.” View this image ›
Eva Hambach / AFP / Getty Images ID: 10757570 ID: 10757680 8. But! The asylum was ALSO used as a means of escaping bad marriages, and in some cases, as a way for unhappy spouses to dump their husband or wife. View this image ›
Eva Hambach / AFP / Getty Images According to Dabbagh , “spouses used lunacy laws to rid themselves of their partners and in abducting their children,” because people could be admitted against their will, by spouses or family members.
ID: 10757601 9. Imagine being stuck in HERE. View this image ›
Eva Hambach / AFP / Getty Images ID: 10757600 10. So long story short: Be careful about who you “read novels” around. View this image ›
Focus Features JK! (Not really).
